docs.lead_paragraph: With an unusual public statement by four Justices, the Supreme Court today refused to hear a case challenging a provision of the Texas death penalty law. The law prohibits telling jurors that if they choose a life sentence instead of the death penalty, the defendant will not be released on parole for at least 40 years. Lawyers for a Texas death row inmate had argued that it was unconstitutional to withhold truthful information that could allay a jury's fears that a dangerous murderer, if not put to death, would soon be out on the street. Texas juries in capital cases are required to assess the defendant's ''future dangerousness'' but at the same time are instructed that ''you are not to consider or discuss'' how long the defendant would actually serve if sentenced to life in prison.

headline.main: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Refuse to Review Texas Death Penalty Case

docs.abstract: Supreme Court, with unusual public statement by four justices, refuses to hear case challenging provision of Texas death penalty law, which prohibits telling jurors that if they choose life sentence instead of death penalty, defendant will not be released on parole for at least 40 years; will decide what sentencing rule should apply to people found guilty of narcotics conspiracies involving more than one illegal drug, typically both powdered cocaine and crack cocaine, which carries much higher penalties under Federal sentencing guidelines; will hear constitutional challenge to 1992 Federal law that requires companies that leave coal mining business to pay lifetime medical benefits to miners who were eligible to receive benefits at time law took effect (M)
docs.snippet: With an unusual public statement by four Justices, the Supreme Court today refused to hear a case challenging a provision of the Texas death penalty law. The law prohibits telling jurors that if they choose a life sentence instead of the death...

docs.lead_paragraph: One was perhaps more homey, the other a bit more cool; one improvised wildly, the other stayed pretty true to the text. But, together, Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton did the town here today -- as only the world's sole superpower couple could.

headline.main: Clintons Present Their Act To an Admiring Argentina

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton visit Buenos Aires, Argentina; Clinton holds televised town hall meeting, genially fielding questions from what producers call 'young leaders' in Buenos Aires and, by two-way link, in Miami and Los Angeles; Univision network says it reached up to 533 million households in 33 countries with Clinton's 'town hall'; Hillary Clinton, in address to 2,500 women, urges greater political involvement for women and promotes family planning, politically charged subject in Latin America; photo (M)
docs.snippet: One was perhaps more homey, the other a bit more cool; one improvised wildly, the other stayed pretty true to the text.    But, together, Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton did the town here today -- as only the world's sole superpower couple could.
